content.raw:
Sure, you can just decline this pull request and create a new one.

But in case you want to try updating this branch with [this](https://bitbucket.org/XB32Z/windows_gazebo7/commits/1be68f73d7c29c781b204c7e5d407450abd812d0) commit, maybe you can give it a try like this:

Pull latest changes from online repo

`hg pull https://bitbucket.org/XB32Z/windows_gazebo7`

Go to this PR's branch

`hg up  Windows_gazebo7`

Merge default (which has the commit) into this branch

`hg merge default`

Commit the merge

`hg commit -m <commit message>`

Push the changes to bitbucket

`hg push`
content.html:
Sure, you can just decline this pull request and create a new one.

But in case you want to try updating this branch with this commit, maybe you can give it a try like this:

Pull latest changes from online repo

hg pull https://bitbucket.org/XB32Z/windows_gazebo7

Go to this PR's branch

hg up Windows_gazebo7

Merge default (which has the commit) into this branch

hg merge default

Commit the merge

hg commit -m <commit message>

Push the changes to bitbucket

hg push

content.raw: Most of the changes that you did that are working Visual Studio and not with nmake are because of bugs in how the the Multi Config generators are handled, see for example my comment in #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2153/windows_gazebo7/diff#comment-14924882 . Once those are solved, both NMake and Visual Studio should work equally fine.
content.html: Most of the changes that you did that are working Visual Studio and not with nmake are because of bugs in how the the Multi Config generators are handled, see for example my comment in #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2153/windows_gazebo7/diff#comment-14924882 . Once those are solved, both NMake and Visual Studio should work equally fine.

To update the pull request, it should be enough to commit the changes to `Windows_gazebo7`.

content.raw:
To get the full path of the binary generated by the target `gazebomsgs_out` you can use the cmake generator expression `$<TARGET_NAME:gazebomsgs_out>`.

This option is supported since CMake v2.8.6, that is the minimum required version by Gazebo : https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v2.8.6/cmake.html#command:add_custom_command .
content.html:
To get the full path of the binary generated by the target gazebomsgs_out you can use the cmake generator expression $<TARGET_NAME:gazebomsgs_out>.

This option is supported since CMake v2.8.6, that is the minimum required version by Gazebo : https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v2.8.6/cmake.html#command:add_custom_command .

content.raw:
If you want to directly define a `float` literal, just add the `f` suffix, as in `0.01f`. 

Ref: http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/floating_literal
content.html:
If you want to directly define a float literal, just add the f suffix, as in 0.01f.

content.raw: Being able to compile Gazebo with the VS generator is quite convenient, but replacing the NMake-based configuration described in existing documentation is a bit destructive. Could it make senso to have a separated `configure-vs.bat` file?
content.html: Being able to compile Gazebo with the VS generator is quite convenient, but replacing the NMake-based configuration described in existing documentation is a bit destructive. Could it make senso to have a separated configure-vs.bat file?

content.raw:
You use tabs instead of spaces here and in several part of the PR. 

Code in Gazebo follows a precise "style", as defined in http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code . 
Unfortunately the standard `code_check.sh` is not Windows friendly, but (at least regarding tabs/spaces) you 
can directly check out the style guide at https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Spaces_vs._Tabs .
content.html:
You use tabs instead of spaces here and in several part of the PR.

Code in Gazebo follows a precise "style", as defined in http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code . Unfortunately the standard code_check.sh is not Windows friendly, but (at least regarding tabs/spaces) you can directly check out the style guide at https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Spaces_vs._Tabs .

content.html: • Could not initiliaze cmds like that with MCVS

content.raw:
* Add a destructor for CameraLensPrivate (defined in CameraLensPrivate.cc)
* variants could not be initialized in this way here so redefined it using a MSDN workaround 
* By using the workaround, the "type" declared l36 has collapsed with a Boost defined variable so I also had to undefined this Microsoft nonsense at the end.
content.html:
• Add a destructor for CameraLensPrivate (defined in CameraLensPrivate.cc)
  • variants could not be initialized in this way here so redefined it using a MSDN workaround
  • By using the workaround, the "type" declared l36 has collapsed with a Boost defined variable so I also had to undefined this Microsoft nonsense at the end.

content.raw: Added CameraLensPrivate.cc to delcare a destructor cf Issue #1776
content.html: Added CameraLensPrivate.cc to delcare a destructor cf Issue #1776

content.raw: * Here the gazebomsgs-out.exe is compiled under /Release in Visual Studio meaning that the CMake had to be changed to this to search in the good directory.
content.html: • Here the gazebomsgs-out.exe is compiled under /Release in Visual Studio meaning that the CMake had to be changed to this to search in the good directory.

content.raw:
* Work around provided by MSDN: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/168958 
* I suspect 60% of the hundreds of thousands of warnings coming from this problem but I couldn't solve it all with this workaround
* DECLSPECIFIER and EXPIMP_TEMPLATE are defined in system.hh along with GZ_MATH_VISIBLE
content.html:
• Work around provided by MSDN: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/168958
  • I suspect 60% of the hundreds of thousands of warnings coming from this problem but I couldn't solve it all with this workaround
  • DECLSPECIFIER and EXPIMP_TEMPLATE are defined in system.hh along with GZ_MATH_VISIBLE
